artist: Otomo Yoshihide / Ozeki Mikito / Mats Gustafsson
title: With Records
description: Released to commemorate the exhibition “Ensembles ’09: With Records” at Gallery 45-8, Tokyo, October 11-November 8, 2009

title: Windows: The Music of Steve Lacy
description: Cover material from a consummate original. Mats brings his Swedish reeds to compositions by Steve Lacy, Cecil Taylor and Mats Gustafsson!

artist: Anders Jormin, Christian Jormin & Mats Gustafsson
title: Opus Apus
description:
"This rare meeting has developed into this exciting CD ”Opus apus”. The title refers to that the
major part of the compositions have got titles from names of birds in Latin."

title: Motum
description: "Motum" means motion, and this is a central theme in the 3 pieces by composer Claudio F Baroni on this album. The concept is central to Baroni's work, and is explored musically and formally in his layered, dynamic, sophisticated style. The breathtaking pieces are taking the listener on a meandering path, starting from the origin of sound. Motum is Baroni's second collaboration with Unsounds. With liner notes by Samuel Vriezen.

title: From Wolves to Whales
description: “The musicians delve deep into the outside schema of jazz amid a largely aggressive mode of attack. With hustling cadences, energized soloing and all the customary trimmings, the band acutely morphs the improv platform with semi-structured song-forms” - Glenn Astarita, All About Jazz

title: Tau Ceti
description: "The young Astral Spirits label continues to punch above its weight with yet another outstanding release." -Mike, Avant Music News

artist: Michiyo Yagi / Paal Nilssen​-​Love / Lasse Marhaug
title: Angular Mass
description: “This record is dense with ideas and the longer tracks might be overwhelming at times, but the musicians are always aware of each other, always listening and keeping the music flowing.” - Nicola Negri

title: PAVILION
description: "The unusual situation here was that they were working in a studio, experimenting, trying out ideas while at the same time being a part of an ongoing art installation."

title: Mechanisms
description: “Besides its unbridled intensity, Ballister seems possessed by positive spirits while gelling to the live element via an emotive, fluid, and overpowering set of protocols, offering thrills-a-nanosecond.” - Glenn Astarita, All About Jazz

title: New Brazilian Funk
description: “New Brazilian Funk feels totally free, organic and full of positive and uplifting energy that will force even the most casual listener to stretch his limbs and experiment his best and most advanced Brazilian dance moves. Please, keep this funky thing coming.” - Eyal Hareuveni, Free Jazz Blog

title: Hurgu!
description: “It’s powerful, speedy, chaotic, but with a high degree of interplay and charm. Improvised, yes, but never out of focus.” - Ronny Wærnes

title: Scaffolding
description: "An interaction that, despite enormous freedom, also led to a setthat was as short as it was consistent.” - Guy Peters

title: Knknighgh (Minimal Poetry For Aram Saroyan)
description: "The band uses short composed materials written by Wooley and those fragmented materials are looped and pushed to the limit, triggered by any of the players in whatever order chosen in the moment." - Clean Feed

title: The Damage is Done
description: "The lines remain remarkably distinguishable even when they converge into such a large sound that it could be mistaken for cacophonic chaos." - Lyn Horton

title: Pokkeherrie
description: "Subtleties, intricacies, complexities, repetitions, basic noise."

title: Battle Pieces 2
description: "The written music and combination of players work through Wooley's composed music that gives way to each player's improvisations and each musician's extended technique." - Mark Corroto, All About Jazz

title: Azimuth (Live at Constellation)
description: "The tape Azimuth (Live at Constellation) features three lengthy group improvisations all marked by a fiery intensity, with the front man's playing less indebted to his usual Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane influences." - Peter Margasak

title: 12 Clarinets in a Fridge
description: "This was a project a long time in the making - Xavier Charles is a not a person you can rush; he has very clear objectives that need the time that they take. When he took interest in the sounds of the appliances in his kitchen, daily sounds that remain unnoticed to most of us, he was to explore listening and perception as part of his music making."

title: Schlager
description: "I actually did not know about this release until looking through the Catalytic website last week. It is mindblowing how locked-in Yeh and Vandermark are on this album." - claire rousay. C. Spencer Yeh: voice, violin, electronics. Ken Vandermark: reeds.

title: Strountes
description: "In Strountes music he is free to work with all his "styles" - and he does! Strountes sees Mats host the saxophones, flutephone & live electronics. Anla Courtis, from Buenos Aires, plays electric guitar, homemade violin, contact mic & pocket Theremin. Courtis has an enigmatic musical presence. A musical mystic, who once studied with Robert Fripp, and also played with minimalist queen Pauline Oliveros together with his band Reynols, completes the trio with his rawness and energy." Mats Gustafsson: Baritone Saxophone, Tenor Saxophone, Slide Saxophone. Anla Courtis: Electric Guitar, Homemade Violin, Electronics, Theremin. Magnus Broo: Trumpet. Maria Eriksson: Vocals, Acoustic Guitar, Toy Piano.

artist: Paul Lytton / Nate Wooley + Ikue Mori & Ken Vandermark
title: The Nows
description: "I absolutely adore this supergroup of performers." - claire rousay. Ikue Mori: Computer. Nate Wooley: Trumpet. Ken Vandermark: Sax. Paul Lytton: Percussion.

title: I Wonder If I Was Screaming
description: " I Wonder If I Was Screaming continued AALY's string of excellent releases and helped cement their reputation as one of the very best working ensembles at the turn of the century." -Brian Olewnick, AllMusic

title: Live at Blå
description: "There are all the violent shrieks and wails one expects from Gustafsson, the polyrhythmic, Paul Lovens-ian drumming of Paal Nilssen-Love and Flaten's updated Mingus style. But there also are enough quiet, almost introspective moments that highlight each musician's technical facility and make the louder portions even more forceful." -Andrey Henkin, All About Jazz

artist: Joe McPhee / Peter Brötzmann / Kent Kessler / Michael Zerang
title: Guts
description: "The quartet of reedmen Joe McPhee and Peter Brötzmann, bassist Kent Kessler and drummer Michael Zerang have come together in a recording called Guts (Okka, 2007) to honor Malachai Ritscher, who died of self-immolation on November 3, 2006, in protest of the war in Iraq." - Lynn Horton, All About Jazz. Peter Brötzmann - Alto Saxophone, Tenor Saxophone, Clarinet, Tárogató; Kent Kessler - Double Bass; Michael Zerang - Drums; Joe McPhee - Trumpet, Alto Saxophone, Tenor Saxophone

title: Ambrosia
description: “Two seasoned improvisors utilizing deep creative vocabularies and serious listening skills. It flows, it scratches, it’s melodic, it’s unpredictable…….it makes perfect sense." - Tim Daisy

title: Legend Street Two
description: "it's a breathless and beautiful tapestry of multiphonic jazz art. Legend Street Two is further evidence why Joe McPhee is the real guy to watch in the 21st century; it feels like he's just getting warmed up"

title: Light and Shade
description: Light and Shade is the latest release by Chicago based composer and percussionist Tim Daisy. A selection of material recorded on various instruments reconstructed, reimagined, and remixed by NYC based electronic musician Ikue Mori. A remote collaboration shaped during a unique moment in time.

title: Elm City Duets
description: "What we have here is a vivacious dialogue between two equals, with precious and incisive arguments by both parts. Your record colection will be incomplete without this!"-Clean Feed. Joe Morris - guitar. Barre Phillips - bass.

artist: Deep Listening Band / Joe McPhee Quartet
title: Unquenchable Fire
description: “On Unquenchable Fire, the musicians have brought the full force of their intelligence and sensitivity to Oliveros’ vision, creating a listening experience both memorable and evocative.” -Florence Wetzel. Deep Listening Band: Pauline Oliveros - accordion. Stuart Dempster - trombone, didjeridu. David Gamper - keyboard, flutes, electronics. Joe McPhee Quartet: Joe McPhee - soprano sax, alto clarinet, casio digital horn. Joe Giardullo - flutes, bass clarinet. Monica Wilson - cello.Karen Jurgens - drums. Text read by Rachel Pollack. 2003

title: Impressions of Jimmy Giuffre
description: "This beautiful set is full of a unique tenderness, and comes out as a very personal statement that should not be missed." -Alain Drouot, All Music

title: From Wolves to Whales
description: “The musicians delve deep into the outside schema of jazz amid a largely aggressive mode of attack. With hustling cadences, energized soloing and all the customary trimmings, the band acutely morphs the improv platform with semi-structured song-forms” - Glenn Astarita, All About Jazz

title: Tau Ceti
description: "The young Astral Spirits label continues to punch above its weight with yet another outstanding release." -Mike, Avant Music News

artist: Michiyo Yagi / Paal Nilssen​-​Love / Lasse Marhaug
title: Angular Mass
description: “This record is dense with ideas and the longer tracks might be overwhelming at times, but the musicians are always aware of each other, always listening and keeping the music flowing.” - Nicola Negri

title: Pes
description: "The string quartet is an instrumental combination most often heard in many different genres of classical music; in fact, it is one of the standard groupings for this music, whereas it is a more rare enterprise in improvised music. Certainly there are examples of string players getting together to improvise, but the results can not so often be compared favorably with great classical string quartets. The Dutch viola player and composer Henneman is making great progress in this area however, as she has found a regular group of musicians to work with, evidenced by the six-year span of recording dates. The difficult task of integrating composition and improvisation is carried out with aplomb by this group: they actually make it sound easy. A nice combination of male and female energy exists in this group, as well as a combination of Dutch musicians and so-called ex-patriot Americans who have settled in the Netherlands. The players are comfortable working in a traditional, melodic, and harmonic manner but also can and do go way out. Everything that happens makes logical sense, and this is music that reveals rich layers of detail upon repeated listenings." - Eugene Chadbourne (All Music)

title: Mechanisms
description: “Besides its unbridled intensity, Ballister seems possessed by positive spirits while gelling to the live element via an emotive, fluid, and overpowering set of protocols, offering thrills-a-nanosecond.” - Glenn Astarita, All About Jazz

title: New Brazilian Funk
description: “New Brazilian Funk feels totally free, organic and full of positive and uplifting energy that will force even the most casual listener to stretch his limbs and experiment his best and most advanced Brazilian dance moves. Please, keep this funky thing coming.” - Eyal Hareuveni, Free Jazz Blog

title: Luke Stewart Exposure Quintet
description: Powerful band and music by Luke Stewart! - Ingebrigt Håker Flaten. Here's an "Onasroc The Magnificent" prediction for you: On July 7th, in the year 2057, NASA inaugurates its time-travel program by going through the hole that's ripped in the fabric of the universe every time "Brown and Gray" from this album is played at full-volume.  - Chris Corsano. Edward Wilkerson, Jr. - Reeds. Ken Vandermark - Reeds. Jim Baker - Piano. Avreeayl Ra - Drums.

title: Scaffolding
description: "An interaction that, despite enormous freedom, also led to a setthat was as short as it was consistent.” - Guy Peters

title: Knknighgh (Minimal Poetry For Aram Saroyan)
description: "The band uses short composed materials written by Wooley and those fragmented materials are looped and pushed to the limit, triggered by any of the players in whatever order chosen in the moment." - Clean Feed

title: The Damage is Done
description: "The lines remain remarkably distinguishable even when they converge into such a large sound that it could be mistaken for cacophonic chaos." - Lyn Horton

title: Pokkeherrie
description: "Subtleties, intricacies, complexities, repetitions, basic noise."

title: Battle Pieces 2
description: "The written music and combination of players work through Wooley's composed music that gives way to each player's improvisations and each musician's extended technique." - Mark Corroto, All About Jazz

title: Azimuth (Live at Constellation)
description: "The tape Azimuth (Live at Constellation) features three lengthy group improvisations all marked by a fiery intensity, with the front man's playing less indebted to his usual Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane influences." - Peter Margasak

title: 12 Clarinets in a Fridge
description: "This was a project a long time in the making - Xavier Charles is a not a person you can rush; he has very clear objectives that need the time that they take. When he took interest in the sounds of the appliances in his kitchen, daily sounds that remain unnoticed to most of us, he was to explore listening and perception as part of his music making."

title: Roadwork 2: Atlanta
description: Recorded by Andrew Wiggins at The Earl, Atlanta on January 31, 2018. Mastered by Dave Zuchowski at One Room Studio.

title: Repeat That, Repeat
description: "The Tentet lays out a silken, sumptuous ensemble sound, constructed from one composition to the next... which unfold at a leisurely pace into glorious peacock-feathers." –Erik van den Berg, Volkskrant
"Electroacoustic chamber pieces for electronics, percussion, homemade percussion, laptop, and found objects" - Piero Scaruffi

title: The Education of Lars Jerry
description: Recorded 12th October 1995 at the Renaissance Society, Chicago.

title: Piazza Pia
description: "Described -- usually by classical music snobs -- as the superlative medium for a composer's thoughts in chamber music, the string quartet is often resistant to massive efforts to free it of ponderous 19th century memories and shove it into the modern era." - JazzWeek

title: Concentric
description: “The ‘center’ implied by the title of the CD is nothing more than the praxis of improvisation, and here we have two masters immersed in that kind of methodology and approach.” - Clean Feed

title: Naancore
description: “The impact that saxophonist Dave Rempis has had on the contemporary improvised music scene extends way beyond Chicago. This duo album with Lasse Marhaug on electronics is a clear indication of how Dave’s work overlaps across many different aesthetics.” - Ken Vandermark

title: Marker
description: "Moor plays electric guitar and from the first strike of pick against string there's no mistaking him. He's amongst the few people on earth who can not only make a guitar sound like it's strung with highly charged telephone cables, but also make that sound right.” - Bill Meyer

title: Tender Music
description: “I was lucky enough to be asked to write the liner notes for this album. What Elisabeth Harnik (piano) and Joelle Leandre (bass & voice) have created together is a recording of improvised music performed at the highest level, with has a compositional clarity that is very, very rare.” - Ken Vandermark

title: (Sit In) The Throne Of Friendship
description: “A warm and heartfelt album, full of inventive compositions, building on various elements of jazz tradition, yet moving it a step further into the future, performed with superb musicianship and equally warm and tight interplay. Play it again!” - Stef, Free Jazz Blog

title: Sliptong
description: “Though Ig Henneman is often known as a composer of new music, she is also an improviser. This trio recording with Ab Baars is one of the last recorded documents of Misha Mengelberg’s work. It is austere, haunting, and beautiful.” - Ken Vandermark

title: And She Speaks: A Collection of Ballads
description: “Few things are as radical as Ab Baars' solo music. From the application of Von Freeman’s influence on tenor to the inspiration of John Carter on clarinet, Ab has created a unique voice in the history of improvised music, one that I continually seek out as a motivator for my own work.” - Ken Vandermark

title: Baro 101
description: “Baro 101 totally undermines the notion that improv is a stale, overly-intellectualised genre for Western, coffee-swilling virtuosos. It’s warm and it swings, engaging and challenging at once. This is, to me, what improv should be, and I would happily place Baro 101 alongside the seminal works of Peter Brotzmann, AMM and John Russell. Time will tell if this has quite the impact those guys did, but I certainly hope so.” - Joseph Burnett

title: Hexane
description: “This is one of my favorite trios, which is not surprising because it features three of my favorite musicians. In addition to Ingebrigt on bass, Icepick includes Chris Corsano on drums, and Nate Wooley on trumpet. The DKV Trio played on a double bill with them in Toronto a few years ago, and that was a gig for the ages!”  - Ken Vandermark

title: New Earth
description: "Sounds like someone stepped on a copy of Mahavishnu Orchestra's "Birds of Fire", put it on the turntable, loved what they heard, and pressed it into a CD. Pure spontaneous music from three of the heaviest in contemporary music."

title: Starters Alternators
description: "The Ex have remained Amsterdam's best kept secret for a decade, despite a plethora of LPs, all with great lyrics... like its predecessors, it's a throat-grabbing, post-punk smacker that also lets in the more hushed, unsettling underbelly of the genre. Whether the band is more restrained, or full-throttle, these Dutchmen remain wired, compelling, and thoughtfully raw... Starters Alternators is a powerful earful of insurgency."

title: Soigne Ta Droite
description: “There is nothing that I love more than composing for and working with a large ensemble. Entr’acte is the most recent iteration of a process for me that’s developed over more than two decades. The band is comprised of an international cast of 10 musical characters who I believe represent the highest levels of the improviser’s art.” - Ken Vandermark

title: Four Improvisations
description: “Free jazz in the hands of masters is the ultimate form of music. This, this is sublime. This record is absolutely stunning.” - Stef, Free Jazz Blog

title: Ambrosia
description: “Mixing conventional and extended techniques, melodies and harmonies, this duo creates a shifting landscape of sound. From swirling clouds that are dark and grainy, to ones that are fragmentary and fleeting, these improvisors use all of their respective instruments to elicit texture and song.” - Paul Acquaro, Free Jazz Blog

title: Seven Storey Mountain V
description: “Nate Wooley is one of the most significant musicians on the contemporary scene, creating and participating in essential projects across many genres: new music, improvised music, noise music…  Seven Storey Mountain is his ever evolving large ensemble, staggering in energy and accomplishment.”  - Ken Vandermark

title: II
description: "Unapologetic, aggressive and bass heavy take on classic free jazz music.Their sound is challenging and cerebral yet contains distinct ebbs and flows of sound that is difficult to ignore." - Pete Larson. Jarrett Gilgore - alto saxophone and clarinet. Luke Stewart - upright bass. Ian McColm - drums.

title: Roman Poems
description: “The cheers of the crowd at the end jar me every time. It's such a perfect creation it's easy to forget this was recorded in front of an audience. Bravo!” - Tom Burris, The Free Jazz Collective

title: Jikan
description: “Like Hairy Bones, another group that features a legendary, innovative reed player (this time, Akira Sakata), and driven by the creative force of Paal’s drumming. Thankfully, Arashi remains an ongoing concern- any chance to hear Akira Sakata fronting a rhythm section like this (with Johan Berthling on bass) is a cause for celebration.”  - Ken Vandermark

title: DKV Trio
description: "Since Vandermark is perpetually searching for ideas to precipitate inspired improvisation, Cherry's masterpiece makes plenty of sense; it was essentially the first extended work of multi-thematic free jazz." -Peter Margasak

title: A Forward Line :: Original Sounds 2004​​-​​2020
description: “Tim Daisy has been a mainstay on the Chicago improvised music scene for nearly two decades, and his work as a drummer, composer, and bandleader has brought him international acclaim. For those less familiar with his music, the overview that A Forward Line provides is a perfect place to start; for those that already celebrate Tim’s contributions, this album is a reminder as to why.” - Ken Vandermark
